text: @Nullable is supported in some places
But the annotation tends to differ
Eclipse uses @NotNull
And lord knows what netbeans uses
Might not be a good idea to include that since someone could potentially try to build with Gradle
My brother uses Netbeans, _cringes_
So is there a way to check whether a channel is private?
I can't see anything in the Slack API, there must be a way to see in the channel code perhaps
<https://api.slack.com/types>
I need to stop leaving my bot on
The object types don't talk about a private channel, only a private group and dm (which is a channel it says)

Ah wait: 
> These channel objects are not the same object type as private channels, which are considered group objects.
Well <@U0N7D6F50> only works in channels that it's been invited
So I don't think it's necessary to discriminate between private and non private channels
<@U061HDV96>: first letter: U = User, G = Group or mpim, C = Channel
<@U08GFT5V5>: well people can invite him for free karma
Good point

text: <@U08GFT5V5>: I was going for something to chain validation requests. Can definitely be improved though and don't mind if I did something bad for Groovy
Looks good to me
I think there needs to be something to be something better than this.valid
My thought would be that, validate runs the regex
is valid should be boolean
Ya, validate wouldn't be visible
Perhaps just assume that if validate() returns null, it's invalid
Slack really can't cope with snippets
Typing is laggy as fuck
Wtf <https://i.imgur.com/Ng3iWap.png>
For me that’s animated reactions
Doesn’t seem reasonable to me that validate, return anything that isn’t boolean
I want to know if a string matches a pattern
that’s different from parsing IMO
what if, validate was replaced with parse?
Perhaps a good idea
And validate would run parse and have a check on it?
Yeah and if the result is null/ it throws an exception then you know it didn’t work
so then you try the next thing
What would isValid do then?
might not need it
since it would only parse if it’s valid
Well how would you check if it's valid then somewhere? :stuck_out_tongue:
Perhaps just put it in isValid?

My thought is, 

```
parse -> validate -> doAction
```
And then register a request or something?
Yeah, that would be in the action
I was thinking connect it to an event
And doAction (which I would change to act) would do whatever with it
I'm trying too hard to overengineer this
Overengineering is nice
<@U08GFT5V5>: what do you think of the following?

text: Slack really needs to improve performance
It even lags when scrolling with snippets
Shouldn’t parse call act if the parsing is successful?
Why does it need to be invoked separately?
<@U08GFT5V5>: well doesn't it only do it when it's valid/successful?
What should be invoked separately?
I see this
It isn’t overriden in HelpRequest
but i assume it’s going to be the same thing there
So I think that having the separate isValid method which only does a null check isn’t that necessary
Well that is because the help request doesn't need a separate isValid check
I don't know what it would check for
we could work under the assumption that if the request is parsed correctly, it just invokes the action
That could work
So introduce some ParseExceptions or something?
Yeah, It might make things neater
RequestParseException, ParseException, RequestException or something else?
I'd go for ParseException
Lol dude, just one of them will be fine
Ya, I'm asking too many questions
Nah not that it’s just I think keeping it “relatively” simple is the way to go
I think the linkbait log output is already bigger than the app
And i just restarted the server
I guess that’s what we get for having 2000 people in a single chat
Alright, should I push the request stuff?
If it works, I’ll merge and deploy
Well it currently only has the HelpRequest
But I was thinking of something
So we currently would have some MessageRequest subclasses
So a lot of logic is redundant
We could implement some kind of parent requests that gather other requests
So there is a MessageParentRequest or something that has some subclasses of MessageRequests and would pass the parsed message to each of those
So that first parse is only done once
Well actually, I was thinking of something like a strategy pattern
Big switch statement
Parse as x
Parse as Y
which ever falls though ends the switch
I think the problem with trying to partially match a message is that the logic gets a bit to complex
If first group matches x then forward second group to y
If that were the case, we’d be better of trying to tokenize the string, then creating an AST to parse it
But i think that would be a tad bit too much over-engineering :joy:
lol
I'm not seeing the purpose of your huge switch statement though
Why would you want a huge switch statement?
Ah i think I misunderstood your idea
You want to pass the request down the inheritance tree
Same problem, trying to partially match the string will make the code pretty complicated… :confused:
But parsing the @botname: everywhere is redundant :confused:
True…
Meh… we can fix it later :joy:
So push the current HelpRequest stuff?
Sounds good
I'm gonna add some documentation first
<@U08GFT5V5>: <https://gitlab.com/nishtahir/linkbait/merge_requests/5>
